sense.name: (cause to) assume upright position
sense.commentary:
NP1 STAND (ADV[orientation])
Includes: STAND UP Note: This sense necessarily entails the UPRIGHT position of NP1. Like sense 2 location is also implied, but the focus is on the upright orientation of the NP1. If the word does not entail this orientation, then go with sense 2.
sense.examples: We had to stand for the entire performance. When it stood upright, it was about twice the height of an elephant. It stood on its hind legs, and belted out the British national anthem. When we are standing, the spine naturally curves both inwards and outwards. Can you stand the bookshelf up? Stand the tamales up in a large steamer or colander with the pinched end up. The dog's hair stood up on end as he growled at us.

sense.name: (cause to) be in a particular location
sense.commentary: NP1 STAND PP[location or quantifier] Note: This sense does not entail UPRIGHT orientation of NP1. If such is entailed then go with sense 1. The sense can be metaphorical. HINT: For many of these examples, you can replace 'stand' with 'be' (or with 'put' for the causative) without a big change in meaning. Such a substitution with examples in sense 1 would be strange. EX: ??? We had to be for the entire performance. (sense 1) The bookshelf was in the corner. (sense 2) ??? Put the tamales in a large steamer (sounds okay, but loses some meaning) Put the bookshelf in the corner.
sense.examples: Trade deficit with India stands at $10 million. We all stand on the shoulders of giants. I want to stand as close to the edge as I can without going over. We stand at the intersection of computers and humanism. The bookshelf stood in the corner. Stand the bookshelf in the corner. The castle stands on a hill. Where do you stand on this issue? Do not use your septic system when surface water is standing on the field.

sense.name: have a particular attribute or feature; be in a particular state
sense.examples: She stands 6 feet tall. I stand corrected. The house stood empty for years. You stand accused of murder, how do you plead?

sense.name: endure, persist or tolerate
sense.examples: Supermarkets stand the test of time. This love won't stand the test of time. If you can't stand the heat, get out of the kitchen. Those shoes really stand up to a lot of wear and tear. Our football team has stood up to adversity a lot this season. He stood up to the racial taunts. I'm standing my ground and I won't give in! Whether you like it or not, the rule stands.

sense.name: male domestic animals such as stallions serve selected females
sense.examples: Muscles Yankee will retire from racing to stand stud at Perretti Farms in Cream Ridge.

sense.name: be in a position to do something
sense.examples: I could stand to lose a few more pounds. If rates rise, you stand to receive less than you paid. Everyone could stand to conserve energy.

sense.name: stand back
sense.commentary: Note: means both "keep one's distance" and "position oneself away from someone or something"
sense.examples: Stand back! Or I will be forced to make my upper thighs look blotchy! He stood back to look at her.

sense.name: Be loyal, unwavering
sense.examples: She stood by her husband in times of trouble. Shortage looming, yet nurses stand fast.

sense.name: Stand firm
sense.commentary: Note: means both "resist/withstand" and "refuse to abandon one's beliefs of opinions"
sense.examples: Stand firm! Don't let them intimidate you! I agree we should stand firm behind the president.

sense.name: Signify, mean, symbolize
sense.examples: What does the Statue of Liberty stand for? T stands for Tab. An 'h' in Greek stands for an 's' in Latin.

sense.name: Watch over as to protect
sense.commentary: Includes: stand guard, stand sentinel, stand watch
sense.examples: The jewels over which they stood guard were stolen. We must stand sentinel to protect ourselves. Tech saavy staff stand watch over their networks.

sense.name: Stand pat
sense.examples: Look for the Lakers to stand pat as the NBA trade deadline looms.

sense.name: Stand still
sense.examples: Please stand still with your feet together for 10 minutes.

sense.name: Arise, get up, be upright
sense.examples: We had to stand up for the entire performance. Can you stand the bookshelf up? My hair stood up when I saw the bear.

sense.name: Refuse to back down, resist, hold water
sense.examples: He stood up for his friend. The balloon theory won't stand up.

sense.name: Stand in
sense.examples: She will stand in for the President in case of absence.

sense.name: Distinguish oneself, be noticable
sense.examples: He stood out as a beacon of humility. She stands out because she's never been afraid to speak her mind.

sense.name: Of ships - steer away from shore
sense.examples: The ship stood out of the bay.

sense.name: Put up with, tolerate
sense.examples: I won't stand for this kind of behavior!

sense.name: Not act or do anything
sense.examples: He just stood by while the Police beat the demonstrators.

sense.name: Stick around, be available
sense.examples: Stand by for the next installment of this article.
